About Me

Hi, my name’s May and I’m a PhD student currently studying inhibitory neuron development with Dr. Christian Mayer. I have extensive experience analyzing largue volumes of biological sequencing data. Besides my PhD, I’m also passionte about user experience researcch and hope to apply the analytical and research skills I’ve gained to build user-friendly digital products.

I am most skilled in: Data Visualization and Quantitative Research

Projects

CRISPR screen project

github.com/mayho3

Using CRISPR to screen important developmental gene technqiues

The goal of the project is to examine how neuronal cell types are affected by the knockout of candidate developmental genes. We accomplish this by injecting the CRISPR-Cas9 molecular construct into neuronal precursors to mutate key developmental genes, followed by sequencing of individual, mature neurons at a later time point. Through the analysis and visualization of the sequencing data, I hope to uncover genes and genetic programs that are critical for the development and specification of inhibitory neurons.

This project is a work-in-progres and a collaboration with a postdoc in my lab.

Experience

Max Planck Institute of Neurobiology

PhD Research Student

September 2018 - Present

neuro.mpg.de/mayer

“As long as our brain is a mystery, the universe, the reflection of the structure of the brain will also be a mystery.”― Santiago Ramón y Cajal

I conduct research on the development of inhibitory neurons by applying statistical techniques like machine learning to analyze genomic data from neurons. I use programming languages such as R and Python for data wrangling and visualization.

Education

IMPRS for Molecular Life Sciences

PhD Neurobiology

2018 - Present

The IMPRS for Molecular Life Sciences: From Biological Structures to Neural Circuits is a center of excellence for the training of PhD students in the areas of biochemistry, cell biology, molecular medicine, neurobiology and structural biology.

Through my graduate school, I’ve attended a number of workshops such as Data Visualization, Scientific Writing, and Graphic Design.

I’ve also won 2nd Best Poster at our graduate school’s bi-annual research seminar.
